description.narrative: New/additional funds to address COVID-19 The contribution aims at proving an example to the GoE of how the national school feeding prgramme may be implemented.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Insatsen innebär ett pilotprojekt vars syfte är att visa en modell på hur det nationella skolmatsprogrammet i Etiopien kan implementeras. Projektet ska bygga upp piloter i 7 skolor i en region (zone) samt bidra med kapacitetsutveckling till andra skolor och regioner så det kan genomföra något liknande på egen hand efter projektets slut.

While the objectives for the school feeding and nutrition programme still stands, separate objectives for the COVID-19 response have been formulated. Objectives (school feeding and nutrition programme) 1. Implementation of nutritional guidelines 2. Support the structural system for effective execution and management of the school feeding programme 3. Strengthening technical capacity of the school feeding program implementers Objectives (COVID-19 response): 1. Ensure physical distancing in public areas to prevent the transmission of COVID-19 2. Improve behaviours around good hygiene and sanitation practices in communities to prevent the spread of COVID-19 3. Strengthening capacity of regional government to establish a model for COVID-19 prevention that can be scaled throughout Amhara region

description.narrative: The intended outcome is to show the government a viable example of how they can implement their policy/law of providing food to schools. The first year, 2016/2017, focused on setting up the systems and structures for the programme plus engaging in advocacy and awareness raising activities to ensure ownership to the programme among the stakeholders in the Amhara region (Waghira Zone and Sekota town). The second year, 2018, has focused on setting up the food processing factory which is now up and running and delivering grain to the schools in the area, plus selling some of the remaining production to the open market. The food processing factory has in addition generated jobs to around 15 persons in an area which is very poor and vulnerable. Further the second year has been about setting up the model kitchens at the schools and 3 model kitchens are now up and running serving 1,500 children every day. During the third year, 2019, the programme has scaled the model kitchens further and is now operational in 5 out of the 7 targeted schools, serving 3,750 children daily. In terms of ownership and systems change, the continuous capacity-building and awareness raising activities on how to run a clean and safe school kitchen and establishing a model for school feeding that can be easily replicated have also yielded results. Through advocacy, the programme have managed to obtain financial allocation from the regional budget for two consecutive years. The programme has also gained traction from other regions including the Addis Ababa City Government, who are now seeking the programme's expertise in their recently launched school-feeding programme for 300,000 children. This confirms the replication potential of the programme. The programme has also successfully started documenting and sharing lessons learnt and best practices of school feeding programmes. Overall, the school feeding programme is progressing well and have met all targets for 2019, except two planned activities; implementing the model kitchen i all 7 target schools and providing training for 150 households on safe and healthy food practices. This will be followed up on during 2020. Results from the COVID-19 response will be followed up on on during 2020.
